thread.title: Eagles' wide receivers drop the ball in loss to Carolina Panthers | Instant Analysis
thread.title_full: Eagles' wide receivers drop the ball in loss to Carolina Panthers | Instant Analysis | NJ.com

author: Mark Eckel | For NJ Advance Media
title: Eagles' wide receivers drop the ball in loss to Carolina Panthers | Instant Analysis
text:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. â€” It was like water torture.
Drop, drop, drop, drop, drop, drop, drop, drop.
The Eagles receivers continued to make life more difficult than it has to be for quarterback Sam Bradford.
Sunday night, in a 27-16 loss to the undefeated Carolina Panthers, the Eagles dropped seven more passes, including two more by team leader Jordan Matthews, who now has nine on the season.
Bradford threw his 10th interception of the season, but it came on a ball that went right through Matthews' hands.
Here are some other observations from the Eagles' loss Sunday night that knocked them out of first place in the NFC East.
Turn it over : The Panthers are a team known for taking care of the football. They had just five turnovers in five games. The Eagles' defense, according to coordinator Bill Davis, sets a goal of three turnovers per game. They got it last night, with three interceptions of Cam Newton -- by Malcom Jenkins, Nolan Carroll and Walter Thurmond. That gives the Eagles 11 on the season. All of last year, they had 12. But the Eagles aren't turning these into wins.
Streak alive : With those turnovers, the Eagles kept alive their league-leading streak of 13 straight games with a turnover. The last time the Eagles defense did not force a turnover was in last year's 53-20 loss to the Green Bay Packers.
Streak over : Panthers running back Jonathan Stewart ran for 119 yards, ending the Eagles' streak of 18 straight games without an opposing back rushing for more than 100 yards. That streak dated back to the fourth game of last season, when Frank Gore, then with the 49ers, went over the 100-yard mark.
Turning the corner : Big free-agent signing cornerback Byron Maxwell took a lot of heat in his first few games with the Eagles. Maxwell has played better in the past few games and played his best game with the Eagles on Sunday night. It's unofficial, but it didn't appear Maxwell allowed a completion all game.
On the other side : Cornerback Nolan Carroll, who had been playing well, struggled, despite a heck of a play for his interception.
Bullet dodged : When Eagles left tackle Jason Peters went down in the first quarter, it looked bad. Turns out, it was just back spasms, which are painful but not season ending. Peters should be fine for a game against the Cowboys when the Eagles return from a bye week.
No problem : Third-year man Matt Tobin replaced Peters, as he has in the past, and did a good job against former Pro Bowl lineman Jared Allen -- until the final moments. Using all of his 12 years experience, Allen beat Tobin for two sacks on the Eagles' final drive of the game.
Falling behind : When the Panthers went 72 yards on their first drive for a touchdown and a 7-0 lead, it marked the sixth time in seven games the opposition scored first. The only game this season the Eagles took the early lead was against the Jets.
Bad loss : In the fourth quarter with the Panthers ahead 21-16, the Eagles faced a third-and-nine from the Panthers' 31. Josh Huff caught a Sam Bradford pass behind the line and lost a yard. Caleb Sturgis' 50-yard attempt was just wide left.
